question.text: In finding the electric field using Gauss law the formula <math><mfenced close="|" open="|" separators="|"><mrow><mover accent="true"><mrow><mi>E</mi></mrow><mo>→</mo></mover></mrow></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>q</mi></mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mo>ε</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub><mfenced close="|" open="|" separators="|"><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></mfenced></mrow></mfrac></math> is applicable. In the formula <math><msub><mrow><mo>ε</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></math> is permittivity of free space, <math><mi>A</mi></math> is the area of Gaussian surface and <math><msub><mrow><mi>q</mi></mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi></mrow></msub></math> is charge enclosed by the Gaussian surface. This equation can be used in which of the following situation?

options.text: Only when the Gaussian surface is an equipotential surface

Only when the Gaussian surface is an equipotential surface and <math><mfenced close="|" open="|" separators="|"><mrow><mover accent="true"><mrow><mi>E</mi></mrow><mo>→</mo></mover></mrow></mfenced></math> is constant on the surface.
Only when <math><mfenced close="|" open="|" separators="|"><mrow><mover accent="true"><mrow><mi>E</mi></mrow><mo>→</mo></mover></mrow></mfenced><mo>=</mo></math> constant on the surface.
For any choice of Gaussian surface.

solution.text:
According to Gauss law of electrostatics, the electric flux through an enclosed surface is given by ϕE=qencε0

From the formula of electric flux, ϕ=E→·ds→

Also, the relation between electric field and electric potential is given by V=E→·dr→

So, the formula E→=qencε0A is only applicable when the Gaussian surface is an equipotential surface and E→ is constant on the surface.
